awd_titl_txt: Integrated Science Practices Enhanced by Computational Thinking (InSPECT)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the integration of computing in STEM teaching and learning. This project will contribute to that effort by developing new curriculum units for high school biology courses that integrate computational thinking within biology. The units will feature inquiry-oriented investigations that will require students to design procedures using a variety of computer-controlled sensors, actuators, video-capture devices, and other technologies to solve open-ended problems. Students will use a simplified visual programming language, called Dataflow, to automate experimental procedures, collect and visualize data, and wirelessly link to data sharing devices. To use these real-time resources effectively, students will need to link the causal (cause and effect) thinking of the natural sciences to the computational thinking skills of computer science. The project will develop 12 curriculum units comprising 6 background units, 3 highly structured set-piece experiments, and 3 open-ended projects. Sets of two background units, 1 set-piece experiment, and one open-ended project will allow students to progress through development of foundational knowledge and experimental skills before taking on the challenge of an open-ended project.  The outcomes of this project have high potential to advance classroom practices in science by identifying ways of using computers and computational thinking to engage students more deeply in the processes and reasoning of scientific inquiry.

The project will conduct design-based research, using the first two project years to develop and validate a pedagogical model of integration between science and computational thinking practices and related activities. In year three, the project will undertake a pilot implementation to test the feasibility of the project's innovations in the biology classes taught by 26 teachers in diverse schools. The project will provide teachers with teaching resources, technology, and professional development designed to enable their students to undertake two science investigations requiring a total of four to six weeks of classes. A mixed-methods research strategy will be employed both to characterize and estimate student gains in applying computational thinking, carrying out science practices, and understanding core biology content knowledge related to ecosystems. Data will be gathered from classroom observations, pretests and posttests, embedded assessments in activities, student screencast reports, interviews with teachers and students, and log data automatically collected by learning software. This variety of data sources will be triangulated to validate research findings from multiple perspectives. Three questions guide the research: A) To what extent and under what conditions are students able to use the project's computational resources to undertake authentic scientific investigations? B) When students are engaged in science experimentation made possible by the resources, approach, and designed tools, what learning gains will be observed in student abilities to perform science practices, exercise computational thinking, and understand biology concepts? What factors are associated with differences in the gains, if any? and C) What kinds of background materials and assistance do teachers require for effective enactments of the intended curriculum? Specifically, how important is teacher background and experience with computers to support student use of technology-enabled experimentation? What was the impact of various kinds of teacher supports on the quality of the classroom enactments.

por.por_cntn:
The Concord Consortium in partnership with ManyLabs designed and introduced computing technologies including Internet-of-Things devices into high school biology to explore learning from the integration of science practices with computational thinking practices in lab-based activities. The InSPECT project worked with high school biology in urban and suburban classrooms to iteratively test curricular activities, programmable kits of sensors and actuators, and lab activities designed to support more authentic scientific practices using computational tools for data acquisition and control for laboratory-based experiments. Through progressive refinements of the computational technology Dataflow software and IoT hardware kits and accompanying curricular activities, the project generated a framework for understanding student agency in learning from data production situated in hands-on materials-rich labs.

The project implemented open source hardware and software: IoT sensors (light, CO2 gas, humidity, temperature), a power relay for actuators like plant lights, and Dataflow software for collecting, processing data and controlling actuators. Teachers and students experienced InSPECT in the science classroom through a set of NGSS-aligned curriculum resources for integrating computational thinking into hands-on laboratory investigations. These materials were developed and tested with eight science teachers and 915 students across diverse public schools throughout Northern California.

InSPECT research contributed concurrently to theory development, new curricular designs, and technology innovation that together enabled biology learning and the support of student epistemic agency in science. With respect to theory development, a data production framework positions students as producers and agents of their own learning through interaction and encounters with physical materials and data (Hardy, Dixon, & Hsi, 2020). With respect to technology innovation, the IoT Dataflow System enabled new types of biology science experiments and computational practices through a visual interface for programming sensor-based experiments and connecting to real-time data (Bondaryk, Hsi, & Van Doren, 2021). The hardware kits were initially prototyped and assembled using low-cost DIY electronics. The software service technology was designed as a cloud-based system and met compliance for classroom use.

When engaging with the InSPECT curriculum that featured a dual learning progression in learning about technology and learning biology using Dataflow during experiments, "messy data" and helping students understand "where data come from" (Hardy, Dixon, Van Doren, & Hsi, 2022). Moreover, students can do authentic science experiments with uncertainty in order to lead to more coherent experimental storylines (Hardy & Dixon, 2020). Expansive forms of activity opened up by dynamic, computational representations in the process of engaging with Dataflow and real-time data experiments (Dixon et al., 2020)  Lab designs that engage students in materiality can support student agency and creative thinking, but there are tradeoffs for student enjoyment and content learning (Hardy et al., in publication).

Our findings suggest that the InSPECT approach improved not only student understanding of science concepts (photosynthesis and cellular respiration in biology class), but engaged students in meaningful and authentic science practices. While teachers and students come to biology class with different background interests and experiences in working with computational tools (programming and electronics), they participated in productive ways with real-time data created and generated with the InSPECT lab activities. Overall, these collective results provide compelling evidence for the use of computational tools for including data in science class, and the feasibility of a dual learning progression in both science and technology learning.

Open source learning resources are shared on the InSPECT project site (http://www.concord.org/inspect) and the GitHub repository.
